1.title: Work on One Sub-Feature at a Time
1.content:
Restricts focus to a single sub-feature per coding session to maintain clarity and prevent scope creep.


Requirements:
- Identify exactly one sub-feature
- Define clear completion criteria
- Avoid mixing multiple features

2.title: Enforce 50 LOC Change Limit
2.content:
Enforces 50-line maximum change limit with explicit override requirement.


Requirements:
- Count all changed lines
- Require LOC_OVERRIDE:<number> for exceptions

3.title: Keep Diffs Minimal
3.content:
Requires minimal, focused code changes to reduce review complexity.


Requirements:
- Make only necessary changes
- Avoid unrelated refactoring
- Group related changes

4.title: Synchronize Comments with Code Changes
4.content:
Mandates comment updates occur simultaneously with code changes.


Requirements:
- Update comments in same commit
- Ensure accuracy
- Include in same PR

5.title: Use Short Sentences in Comments
5.content:
Limits comment sentences to 20 words maximum for readability.


Requirements:
- Maximum 20 words per sentence
- Break complex thoughts
- Avoid run-ons

6.title: Use Simple English Vocabulary
6.content:
Requires everyday vocabulary accessible to 8th-grade reading level.


Requirements:
- Use common words
- Avoid academic vocabulary
- Target middle school comprehension

7.title: Avoid Unexplained Technical Jargon
7.content:
Prohibits technical jargon without plain English explanations.


Requirements:
- Avoid domain terminology
- Use "meaning: <plain words>" for necessary terms

8.title: Use Active Voice
8.content:
Mandates active voice for clearer communication.


Requirements:
- Use subject-verb-object structure
- Avoid passive constructions

9.title: Use Bullets for Step Explanations
9.content:
Specifies bullet point format for procedural explanations.


Requirements:
- Use bullets for sequential steps
- Start with action verbs
- Keep atomic

10.title: Explain Design Decisions Not Code
10.content:
Directs comments toward rationale rather than code restatement.


Requirements:
- Explain design choices
- Document trade-offs
- Focus on intent

11.title: Include Comprehensive File Headers
11.content:
Requires file headers explaining purpose, dependencies, contracts, risks.


Requirements:
- What: purpose
- Why: rationale
- Reads/Writes: data
- Contracts: agreements
- Risks: issues

12.title: Document Import Rationale
12.content:
Mandates organized import documentation with rationale.


Requirements:
- Group imports (stdlib/third-party/local)
- Explain purpose
- Justify dependencies

13.title: Document Public APIs Completely
13.content:
Specifies comprehensive API documentation covering purpose, behavior, errors, security.


Requirements:
- WHAT: purpose
- WHY: rationale
- Steps: sequence
- Inputs/Outputs: contracts
- Fails/Throws: errors
- Security: notes

14.title: Document Non-Obvious Variables
14.content:
Requires detailed variable documentation including meaning, units, ranges, rationale.


Requirements:
- Meaning: purpose
- Units: context
- Range: values
- Reason: design

15.title: Provide Logic PLAN/RATIONALE Blocks
15.content:
Mandates pre-logic explanation blocks for complex conditional/iterative code.


Requirements:
- Place before complex if/loops
- Use bulleted format
- Explain reasoning

16.title: Document Configuration Settings
16.content:
Requires configuration documentation including safety rationale and constraints.


Requirements:
- Explain purpose
- Document safe defaults
- Specify allowed ranges
- Justify safety

17.title: Document Service Business Rules
17.content:
Mandates business rule documentation and external dependency mapping.


Requirements:
- State business rule
- Document APIs/DBs accessed
- Explain boundaries

18.title: Document Logging Purpose and Rules
18.content:
Specifies logging purpose, data protection, traceability requirements.


Requirements:
- Document what/why logged
- Specify redaction rules
- Require traceId

19.title: Document Receipt Audit Trails
19.content:
Defines audit trail requirements with timestamp and context data.


Requirements:
- Document decisions
- Include ts_utc, monotonic_hw_time_ms, action, result, traceId, policy_snapshot_hash

20.title: Document Database Migration Safety
20.content:
Requires migration justification, zero-downtime strategy, recovery procedures.


Requirements:
- Explain why now
- Document online-safe plan
- Specify rollback
- Include cutover flag

21.title: Document Blob Storage Specifications
21.content:
Mandates binary data documentation including format, size, paths, privacy.


Requirements:
- Document format
- Specify size limits
- Define storage paths
- Document privacy controls

22.title: Document Backup Operations
22.content:
Specifies backup operational parameters, retention, verification.


Requirements:
- Document schedule
- Specify retention
- Define restore tests
- Document verification

23.title: Document Audit Trail Integrity
23.content:
Defines audit immutability, authorship, integrity verification.


Requirements:
- Document append-only
- Specify writers
- Define integrity checks (hash/signature)

24.title: Prohibit Secrets and PII in Comments
24.content:
Prohibits sensitive information; mandates synthetic test data.


Requirements:
- No secrets/PII
- Use synthetic data
- Redact sensitive information

25.title: Enforce Output Format Standards
25.content:
Restricts output to Unified Diff, New File, or JSON only.


Requirements:
- Use Unified Diff for changes
- New File for creation
- JSON for config

26.title: Enforce TODO Accountability
26.content:
Requires accountability for unfinished work with owner, date, ticket.


Requirements:
- Require owner
- Mandate due date
- Require ticket
- Allow WAIVER with end date

27.title: Enforce Policy and Contract Links
27.content:
Requires explicit linking to governing contracts/policies.


Requirements:
- Reference contracts
- Link to policies
- Cite specifications
- Document compliance

28.title: Maintain Complete Documentation Coverage
28.content:
Mandates comprehensive documentation across all required locations.


Requirements:
- Update headers
- Maintain imports
- Document functions
- Annotate variables
- Provide logic PLANs

29.title: Include Quantitative Context
29.content:
Requires quantitative context for values including units, ranges.


Requirements:
- Specify units
- Document ranges
- Provide constraints
- Include scaling factors

30.title: Synchronize Comment and Code Presentation
30.content:
Requires synchronized display of code and comment changes.


Requirements:
- Show comment edits with code
- Use unified diff
- Maintain synchronization

31.title: Prioritize Determinism Over Speed
31.content:
Reproducible test runs are superior to fast but flaky runs.


Requirements:
- Configure test frameworks to prioritize reproducible outcomes over execution speed.

32.title: Eliminate Test-Result Caching
32.content:
Disable or purge all framework caches before every run.


Requirements:
- Treat cached test discovery or compiled output as defect sources.

33.title: Enforce Hermetic Test Runs
33.content:
Tests must not access network, system clocks, global OS state, or previous runs.


Requirements:
- All tests operate in complete isolation without external dependencies.

34.title: Maintain Test Independence
34.content:
Tests must pass when run alone or in any sequence.


Requirements:
- Each test must be completely self-contained without shared state.

35.title: Maintain Standard Repository Structure
35.content:
Use src/, tests/ with subdirectories unit/, component/, integration/, fixtures/, helpers/.


Requirements:
- Adhere to standardized directory hierarchy with clear separation.

36.title: Use Standard Test Naming Conventions
36.content:
Python: test_*.py or *_test.py; TypeScript/JavaScript: *.test.(ts|js) or *.spec.(ts|js).


Requirements:
- Follow established naming patterns for automatic test discovery.

37.title: Purge Cache Directories Pre-Execution
37.content:
Delete Python, Node.js, and tooling caches before test execution.


Requirements:
- Remove all designated cache directories before test execution begins.

38.title: Disable Framework Caching
38.content:
Use framework-specific flags to disable caching mechanisms.


Requirements:
- Configure pytest, Jest, Vitest, Mocha with explicit cache-disabling flags.

39.title: Maintain Unit Test Purity
39.content:
Unit tests must be pure functions with no I/O, network, or time dependencies.


Requirements:
- Unit tests operate without external dependencies, network calls, or time-based behavior.

40.title: Use Table-Driven Test Structure
40.content:
Unit tests must use table-driven tests for clarity.


Requirements:
- Employ table-driven patterns with test cases in structured data format.

41.title: Use In-Memory Doubles for Component Tests
41.content:
Component tests must use in-memory doubles only for cross-module interactions.


Requirements:
- Employ in-memory test doubles (mocks, stubs, fakes) avoiding real external systems.

42.title: Use Real Adapters for Integration Tests
42.content:
Integration tests must use real adapters with isolated instances.


Requirements:
- Employ real adapters and drivers with in-process instances or containerized dependencies.

43.title: Prohibit Internet Access in Tests
43.content:
No calls to public Internet in unit, component, or integration tests.


Requirements:
- Tests must not make calls to public Internet services or external APIs.

44.title: Control Randomness and Time
44.content:
All randomness must be seeded; time must be frozen or explicitly controlled.


Requirements:
- Use TEST_RANDOM_SEED for randomness and time-freezing helpers for temporal behavior.

45.title: Prohibit Test Retries
45.content:
Flaky tests are bugs; do not mask with retries.


Requirements:
- Test frameworks must not employ automatic retry mechanisms.

46.title: Organize Fixtures and Data
46.content:
Fixtures under tests/fixtures/, read-only, prefer synthetic data, hash large fixtures.


Requirements:
- Locate fixtures in designated directory, use read-only access, prefer synthetic data, record hashes for large fixtures.

47.title: Generate Test Evidence
47.content:
Emit jUnit XML reports and run manifest with seeds, versions, and hashes.


Requirements:
- Produce standardized machine-readable output artifacts for each test execution.

48.title: Design AI-Generated Tests Deterministically
48.content:
Assume cache purging, use TEST_RANDOM_SEED, compose hermetic tests.


Requirements:
- AI-generated tests must be deterministic, hermetic, and cache-independent.

49.title: Organize AI-Generated Tests Properly
49.content:
Place tests in correct directories, use pure helpers, minimize dependencies.


Requirements:
- Follow directory structure, create pure helper functions, prefer standard libraries.

50.title: Ensure AI-Generated Test Quality
50.content:
Limit test scope, provide complete implementations, create actionable failures.


Requirements:
- Tests must be focused, complete, runnable, and have clear failure messages.

51.title: Enforce Quality Gates
51.content:
All tests must pass, no network access, valid artifacts, cache elimination verified.


Requirements:
- Test runs succeed only when meeting all quality criteria.

52.title: Conduct Comprehensive Test Reviews
52.content:
Verify determinism, completeness, organization, harness usage, artifacts, cache elimination.


Requirements:
- Code reviews must validate all test quality aspects before approval.

53.title: Require Schema Version in Logs
53.content:
All log entries must include the log_schema_version field set to "1.0" to ensure consistent parsing and schema validation across all logging systems.


Requirements:
- The `log_schema_version: "1.0"` field must be present in every JSONL log entry.

54.title: Use JSONL Format for Logs
54.content:
All log entries must use JSONL format with exactly one JSON object per line for consistent parsing and processing.


Requirements:
- Format: ONE JSON object per line (JSONL)

55.title: Standardize Timestamp Format
55.content:
All timestamps must use ISO-8601 UTC format with monotonic hardware time for precise ordering.


Requirements:
- Timestamps: ISO-8601 with Z (UTC). Include monotonic_hw_time_ms for ordering

56.title: Require Monotonic Time Precision
56.content:
Use high-precision monotonic time sources and convert to milliseconds for consistent timing measurements.


Requirements:
- Monotonic precision: use perf_counter_ns() (Python) / performance.now() (TS), store ms (rounded) from ns

57.title: Enforce UTF-8 Encoding
57.content:
Ensure consistent character encoding without BOM and prevent multi-line log entries.


Requirements:
- Encoding: UTF-8 only, no BOM. No multi-line logs

58.title: Ensure Cross-Platform Compatibility
58.content:
Maintain log integrity across Windows and other platforms with proper line endings and path length limits.


Requirements:
- Windows/laptop: CRLF-safe, append with flush to avoid partial lines. Keep path length ‚â§ 240 chars

59.title: Define Output Destination Rules
59.content:
Specify different output destinations for development vs production environments.


Requirements:
- Output: dev ‚Üí console + file; prod ‚Üí file/stream (ship to aggregator). Rotation handled by platform

60.title: Require Timestamp Fields
60.content:
All log entries must include both UTC and monotonic hardware timestamps for temporal correlation.


Requirements:
- ts_utc, monotonic_hw_time_ms required in all logs

61.title: Enforce Log Level Enumeration
61.content:
Standardize log level values to ensure consistent severity classification across all services.


Requirements:
- level: TRACE|DEBUG|INFO|WARN|ERROR|FATAL required in all logs

62.title: Require Service Identification
62.content:
All logs must include service metadata for proper attribution and filtering in distributed systems.


Requirements:
- service, version, env, host required in all logs

63.title: Enforce Distributed Tracing Context
63.content:
Implement W3C trace context propagation and generate missing tracing identifiers.


Requirements:
- traceId, spanId, parentSpanId (W3C trace context) required. If missing, generate and propagate

64.title: Do Exactly What's Asked
64.content:
If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.


Requirements:
- If your friend asks you to make a peanut butter sandwich, don't add jelly unless they ask for it. Follow instructions exactly without adding your own ideas.

65.title: Only Use Information You're Given
65.content:
If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.


Requirements:
- If you're baking cookies and the recipe doesn't say how much sugar to use, stop and ask. Don't guess or make up an amount.

66.title: Protect People's Privacy
66.content:
Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.


Requirements:
- Treat everyone's personal information like a secret diary. Don't look at it, don't share it, and definitely don't write it down where others can see it.

67.title: Use Settings Files, Not Hardcoded Numbers
67.content:
Instead of writing 'use 10 apples' in your recipe, write 'use [number] apples' and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.


Requirements:
- Instead of writing 'use 10 apples' in your recipe, write 'use [number] apples' and keep the number 10 in a separate note. This way you can easily change to 12 apples later.

68.title: Keep Good Records
68.content:
Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.


Requirements:
- Like keeping a science lab notebook - write down what you did, when you did it, and what happened. Use the format your teacher asks for, and don't add extra stuff they didn't request.

69.title: Never Break Things During Updates
69.content:
When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.


Requirements:
- When updating a video game, you should still be able to play while it updates. If the update causes problems, you can instantly switch back to the old version.

70.title: Make Things Fast
70.content:
Optimize performance for all operations. Like a fast computer game - everything should respond quickly, not make people wait.


Requirements:
- Optimize performance for all operations and user interactions
- Ensure response times meet performance targets
- Profile and optimize slow operations

71.title: Be Honest About AI Decisions
71.content:
When AI suggests something, it should say:


Requirements:
- When AI suggests something, it should say:

72.title: Check Your Data
72.content:
Make sure the AI's training data is like a fair test - balanced questions, up-to-date information, and correct answers.


Requirements:
- Make sure the AI's training data is like a fair test - balanced questions, up-to-date information, and correct answers.

73.title: Keep AI Safe
73.content:
AI should only work in a special 'playground' (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.


Requirements:
- AI should only work in a special 'playground' (sandbox) away from real computers. It can look at code and make suggestions, but never actually run code on people's machines.

74.title: Learn from Mistakes
74.content:
When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like you learn from getting test questions wrong.


Requirements:
- When the AI gets something wrong, it should remember that mistake and get smarter, just like you learn from getting test questions wrong.

75.title: Test Everything
75.content:
Always try things out before saying they work. Don't break things that already work. Test both simple cases and tricky situations.


Requirements:
- Always try things out before saying they work. Don't break things that already work. Test both simple cases and tricky situations.

76.title: Write Good Instructions
76.content:
Give people working examples they can try themselves, clear explanations of how to use things, and troubleshooting guides for when things go wrong.


Requirements:
- Give people working examples they can try themselves, clear explanations of how to use things, and troubleshooting guides for when things go wrong.

77.title: Keep Good Logs
77.content:
Write clear notes that are easy to read, use special tracking numbers to follow requests through the system, and measure both technical numbers and business results.


Requirements:
- Write clear notes that are easy to read, use special tracking numbers to follow requests through the system, and measure both technical numbers and business results.

78.title: Make Changes Easy to Undo
78.content:
Prefer adding new features rather than changing old ones. Use on/off switches for features. Write down how to go back if something doesn't work.


Requirements:
- Prefer adding new features rather than changing old ones. Use on/off switches for features. Write down how to go back if something doesn't work.

79.title: Make Things Repeatable
79.content:
Write down exactly what ingredients (versions) you used. Don't depend on special kitchen equipment (computer setups). Include simple steps so others can recreate your work.


Requirements:
- Write down exactly what ingredients (versions) you used. Don't depend on special kitchen equipment (computer setups). Include simple steps so others can recreate your work.

80.title: Keep Different Parts Separate
80.content:
The display screen (user interface) only shows information. The thinking part (business logic) only does calculations. Never mix these two jobs.


Requirements:
- The display screen (user interface) only shows information. The thinking part (business logic) only does calculations. Never mix these two jobs.

81.title: Be Fair to Everyone
81.content:
Use clear, simple language everyone can understand. Don't use tricky designs that might confuse people. Make sure people with disabilities can use everything.


Requirements:
- Use clear, simple language everyone can understand. Don't use tricky designs that might confuse people. Make sure people with disabilities can use everything.

82.title: Make All 20 Modules Look the Same
82.content:
All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.


Requirements:
- All 18 tools should use the same buttons, menus, and look. Like different rooms in the same house - they have the same light switches and door handles.

83.title: Process Data Locally First
83.content:
Process data on the local device first before sending to servers. Like doing homework at your desk before turning it in - handle what you can locally to reduce delays and server load.


Requirements:
- Process data locally when possible before transmission
- Minimize server round-trips by doing local computation
- Only send necessary data to remote services

84.title: Don't Make People Configure Before Using
84.content:
Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.


Requirements:
- Things should work right out of the box. Like a new video game - you can start playing immediately, and only set up complex controls later if you want.

85.title: Show Information Gradually
85.content:
Show information to users gradually, not all at once. Like a storybook - reveal pages one at a time so people can understand each part before moving to the next.


Requirements:
- Present information in progressive disclosure format
- Show essential information first, details on demand
- Avoid overwhelming users with too much information at once

86.title: Organize Features Clearly
86.content:
18 Main Areas ‚Üí Specific Features ‚Üí Detailed Tools Like a school: School ‚Üí Grade Levels ‚Üí Classrooms ‚Üí Subjects


Requirements:
- 18 Main Areas ‚Üí Specific Features ‚Üí Detailed Tools Like a school: School ‚Üí Grade Levels ‚Üí Classrooms ‚Üí Subjects

87.title: Be Smart About Data
87.content:
Be intelligent about how you handle data - use it efficiently and only when needed. Like a smart shopping list - only get what you need, when you need it.


Requirements:
- Use data efficiently and only when necessary
- Cache data appropriately to avoid redundant operations
- Minimize data transfer and storage requirements

88.title: Work Without Internet
88.content:
Core features must work offline, like being able to write in a notebook when you don't have WiFi. Save actions and sync when you're back online.


Requirements:
- Core features must work offline, like being able to write in a notebook when you don't have WiFi. Save actions and sync when you're back online.

89.title: Register Modules the Same Way
89.content:
All 18 modules should sign up using the same process, like every student using the same enrollment form.


Requirements:
- All 18 modules should sign up using the same process, like every student using the same enrollment form.

90.title: Make All Modules Feel Like One Product
90.content:
Use the same command names everywhere, make status indicators look the same, handle errors the same way - like different apps made by the same company.


Requirements:
- Use the same command names everywhere, make status indicators look the same, handle errors the same way - like different apps made by the same company.

91.title: Design for Quick Adoption
91.content:
Design systems so new users can start using them quickly without extensive training. Like a simple video game - you can play immediately, and learn advanced moves later.


Requirements:
- Ensure systems work out of the box with minimal setup
- Provide clear onboarding paths for new users
- Design for intuitive use without extensive documentation

92.title: Test User Experience
92.content:
Test how users actually experience your system, not just if it works. Like taste-testing food before serving - make sure it's good for the people eating it, not just technically correct.


Requirements:
- Test user experience and usability, not just functionality
- Gather feedback from actual users during testing
- Validate that the system meets user needs and expectations

93.title: Solve Real Developer Problems
93.content:
Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.


Requirements:
- Every feature must fix a real frustration developers face, like making homework easier by having better tools.

94.title: Help People Work Better
94.content:
Build tools that help people work better and more efficiently. Like giving someone a better tool for their job - it should make their work easier and more effective.


Requirements:
- Design tools that improve productivity and workflow
- Solve real problems developers and users face
- Provide clear value and efficiency gains

95.title: Prevent Problems Before They Happen
95.content:
Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.


Requirements:
- Stop issues before they become big problems, like fixing a small leak before it floods the house.

96.title: Be Extra Careful with Private Data
96.content:
Be extremely careful when handling private or sensitive data. Like locking a diary - treat personal information with extra security and respect.


Requirements:
- Implement additional security measures for private data
- Validate all access to sensitive information
- Follow strict privacy and data protection protocols

97.title: Don't Make People Think Too Hard
97.content:
Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.


Requirements:
- Fix common issues with one click, give suggestions without interrupting, automate boring tasks, teach as you go - like having a helpful friend.

98.title: MMM Engine - Change Behavior
98.content:
Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.


Requirements:
- Help people stop making the same mistakes, increase use of best practices, reduce need for manual fixes, help people solve problems themselves - like a good habit coach.

99.title: Detection Engine - Be Accurate
99.content:
The detection engine must be accurate and reliable. Like a good security system - it should correctly identify real problems without false alarms.


Requirements:
- Ensure detection accuracy and minimize false positives
- Validate detection results before reporting
- Maintain high precision and recall in problem detection

100.title: Risk Modules - Safety First
100.content:
Never make situations worse, always provide undo options, support gradual improvements, verify before big changes - like safety rules in science lab.


Requirements:
- Never make situations worse, always provide undo options, support gradual improvements, verify before big changes - like safety rules in science lab.

101.title: Success Dashboards - Show Business Value
101.content:
Connect engineering work to company results, show money saved and time gained, track both current and future benefits - like showing how studying leads to better grades.


Requirements:
- Connect engineering work to company results, show money saved and time gained, track both current and future benefits - like showing how studying leads to better grades.

102.title: Use All Platform Features
102.content:
Use all our built-in tools:


Requirements:
- Use all our built-in tools:

103.title: Process Data Quickly
103.content:
Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.


Requirements:
- Handle urgent data in less than 1 second (like answering important texts immediately), group less important data (like checking regular mail once a day), check data quality as it comes in.

104.title: Help Without Interrupting
104.content:
Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.


Requirements:
- Give help when needed, not before (like waiting to be asked), match help to how complex the task is (like simple vs complex instructions), let experts turn off basic help.

105.title: Handle Emergencies Well
105.content:
Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.


Requirements:
- Make the right action obvious (like big red stop button), provide one-click solutions, offer multiple ways to recover, show clear progress updates - like good emergency instructions.

106.title: Make Developers Happier
106.content:
Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.


Requirements:
- Reduce time spent switching between tasks, cut down on boring repetitive work, increase time spent on meaningful coding, build confidence in deployments - like making schoolwork more enjoyable.

107.title: Track Problems You Prevent
107.content:
Count security issues caught early, track deployment failures avoided, measure knowledge gaps found and fixed, watch technical debt prevented - like counting accidents that didn't happen because of safety measures.


Requirements:
- Count security issues caught early, track deployment failures avoided, measure knowledge gaps found and fixed, watch technical debt prevented - like counting accidents that didn't happen because of safety measures.

108.title: Build Compliance into Workflow
108.content:
Check rules automatically during development, monitor compliance in real-time, generate audit reports easily, assess impact of rule changes - like having built-in spell check while writing.


Requirements:
- Check rules automatically during development, monitor compliance in real-time, generate audit reports easily, assess impact of rule changes - like having built-in spell check while writing.

109.title: Security Should Help, Not Block
109.content:
Security tips shouldn't break concentration, automate common security fixes, explain security rules in simple terms, prioritize security risks by importance - like friendly security guards rather than prison guards.


Requirements:
- Security tips shouldn't break concentration, automate common security fixes, explain security rules in simple terms, prioritize security risks by importance - like friendly security guards rather than prison guards.

110.title: Support Gradual Adoption
110.content:
Let teams start with 3-5 most useful modules, each module should work well on its own, show clear paths to add more modules, provide value at every step - like learning math starting with addition, then multiplication.


Requirements:
- Let teams start with 3-5 most useful modules, each module should work well on its own, show clear paths to add more modules, provide value at every step - like learning math starting with addition, then multiplication.

111.title: Scale from Small to Huge
111.content:
Work for 1 developer or 10,000, handle 100 events per day or 10 million, support simple systems and complex ones, meet basic needs and strict regulations - like a playground that works for both small kids and professional athletes.


Requirements:
- Work for 1 developer or 10,000, handle 100 events per day or 10 million, support simple systems and complex ones, meet basic needs and strict regulations - like a playground that works for both small kids and professional athletes.

112.title: Build for Real Team Work
112.content:
Make collaboration natural and easy, help teams share knowledge automatically, reduce meetings and emails through better tools, make it easy to help each other without interrupting work - like good group project tools.


Requirements:

313.title: Stop Conditions ‚Üí GSMD Error Codes  - Writing outside SOT tree .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_SOT_VIOLATION`
313.content:
Stop Conditions ‚Üí GSMD Error Codes**  - Writing outside SOT tree .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_SOT_VIOLATION`  
- Attempt to modify existing snapshot ............... `ERROR:GSMD_MUTATION_DENIED`  
- Hash mismatch vs `snapshot_hash` .................. `ERROR:GSMD_HASH_MISMATCH`  
- Missing/invalid signature or `kid` ................ `ERROR:GSMD_SIGNATURE_MISSING`  
- Invalid evaluation_point .......................... `ERROR:GSMD_EVALPOINT_INVALID`  
- Receipt missing required fields ................... `ERROR:GSMD_RECEIPT_FIELDS_MISSING`  
- Override missing ttl/approvals/signature .......... `ERROR:GSMD_OVERRIDE_INVALID`  
- Approvals < 2 on override ......................... `ERROR:GSMD_APPROVALS_INSUFFICIENT`  
- Manifest verify (hash/Merkle) fail ................ `ERROR:GSMD_MANIFEST_INVALID`  
- Decision not in allowed set ....................... `ERROR:GSMD_DECISION_INVALID`  
- Privacy redaction not applied ..................... `ERROR:GSMD_PRIVACY_DRIFT`  
- Tests/fixtures absent for declared policy ......... `ERROR:GSMD_TESTS_MISSING`  
- Return contract not honored ....................... `ERROR:GSMD_RETURN_CONTRACT_VIOLATION`

# Simple Code Readability Rules (Human-Understandable)

 **Purpose:** Make code so simple that anyone can understand it, even an 8th grader. Follow Martin Fowler's principle: "Good programmers write code that humans can understand."

## Scope
Applies to all code, comments, and documentation. Keep changes small and consistent across the codebase.

---

## Basic Readability Rules


Requirements:
- Self-Audit Before Output (GSMD)**  - [ ] Not editing existing `gsmd/**`; new version only when needed
- - [ ] Snapshot patterns/fields valid; `snapshot_hash` recomputes
- - [ ] Evaluation point valid; decision ‚àà {pass,warn,soft_block,hard_block}
- - [ ] Receipt fields complete and signed; values sourced from snapshot
- - [ ] Overrides time-boxed (ttl) with ‚â•2 approvals; signed
- - [ ] CI gates added (`gsmd-check`, manifest build/verify)
- - [ ] Privacy redactions applied; no PII/secrets in logs or receipts
- - [ ] Output matches allowed return contract
- ---

342.title: ENFORCE Simple Level- MANDATORY: Every line of code must be understandable by an 8th grader
342.content:
ENFORCE Simple Level**- **MANDATORY**: Every line of code must be understandable by an 8th grader
- **MANDATORY**: No technical jargon without explanation
- **MANDATORY**: Use simple, everyday words
- **MANDATORY**: Break complex operations into simple steps
- **MANDATORY**: Write code that reads like plain English
- **MANDATORY**: If an 8th grader can't understand it, rewrite it

---

## Stop Conditions ‚Üí Error Codes (must refuse & escalate)

**ERROR:ADVANCED_CONCEPT_USED** ‚Äî Advanced programming concept detected (closures, decorators, etc.)

**ERROR:COMPLEX_DATA_STRUCTURE** ‚Äî Complex data structure used (nested objects, hash maps, etc.)

**ERROR:JARGON_DETECTED** ‚Äî Technical jargon without explanation found

**ERROR:MENTAL_GYMNASTICS** ‚Äî Complex one-liner or nested ternary detected

**ERROR:ABBREVIATION_USED** ‚Äî Abbreviation used instead of full word

**ERROR:FUNCTION_TOO_LONG** ‚Äî Function exceeds 20 lines

**ERROR:NESTED_COMPLEXITY** ‚Äî Nested conditions or complex control flow

**ERROR:READABILITY_FAIL** ‚Äî Code not understandable at 8th-grade level

**ERROR:TECHNICAL_LANGUAGE** ‚Äî Technical language used instead of business language

**ERROR:MISSING_EXPLANATION** ‚Äî Complex concept lacks explanation

**ERROR:COMPLEX_STRING_OPS** ‚Äî Advanced string manipulation detected

**ERROR:COMPLEX_ERROR_HANDLING** ‚Äî Try-catch or complex error handling

**ERROR:COMPLEX_CONTROL_FLOW** ‚Äî Switch, ternary, or recursion detected

**ERROR:COMPLEX_FUNCTIONS** ‚Äî Function overloading or higher-order functions

**ERROR:COMPLEX_ARRAYS** ‚Äî Array methods or complex array operations

**ERROR:COMPLEX_LOGIC** ‚Äî Boolean algebra or bitwise operations

**ERROR:ADVANCED_LANGUAGE_FEATURES** ‚Äî Generics, decorators, or annotations

**ERROR:ADVANCED_LIBRARIES** ‚Äî Third-party libraries or frameworks

**ERROR:SIMPLE_LEVEL_VIOLATION** ‚Äî Code fails 8th-grade readability test



# Good: Simple, readable code
def calculate_total_price(quantity, unit_price, tax_rate):
    # Calculate the base cost before tax

357.title: Rule Conflict Resolution Framework
357.content:
Establish formal conflict resolution when testing rules contradict other constitutional rules. Security rules always take precedence over testing requirements.


Requirements:
- Implement automated conflict detection between testing and master constitution rules
- Document resolution path in test execution receipts
- Maintain conflict resolution audit trail for compliance evidence

358.title: Cross-Constitution Validation Gateway
358.content:
Validate no contradictions exist between Testing Constitution and Master Constitution documents. Ensure testing requirements don't violate core system principles.


Requirements:
- Static analysis of normalized rule graphs across all constitutional documents
- Fail CI on detection of mutually exclusive requirements
- Generate machine-readable conflict report with specific rule_id mappings

359.title: Module Identity Integrity Validation
359.content:
Ensure Module IDs (M01-M20) maintain consistent identity mapping across GSMD folders, Extension modules, and policy version IDs used by test systems.


Requirements:
- Validate 1:1 mapping integrity across all module identity stores
- Fail fast on detection of unmapped or duplicate module IDs
- Maintain module identity registry as testing source of truth

360.title: Version Compatibility Matrix Enforcement
360.content:
Standardize and enforce version compatibility between Testing Constitution and Master/Module rule sets through automated matrix validation.


Requirements:
- Enforce semantic version format X.Y.Z across all constitutional rule files
- Generate compatibility matrix artifact during CI pipeline execution
- Block deployments on version compatibility violations

361.title: Test Lifecycle Coverage Mandate
361.content:
Require comprehensive test coverage for all system lifecycle states including deprecation, migration, rollback, and configuration inheritance scenarios.


Requirements:
- Provide explicitly named tests for each defined lifecycle state
- Emit verifiable receipts proving exercise of each lifecycle scenario
- Maintain lifecycle test coverage metrics and compliance evidence

362.title: Automated Compliance Evidence Generation
362.content:
Mandate automated generation of compliance evidence bundles for every PR proving constitutional adherence across all rule sets.


Requirements:
- Produce machine-readable evidence including conflict analysis and validation results
- Attach compliance evidence artifact to CI execution runs
- Store receipt pointers for all compliance validation events

363.title: Testing Rule Metadata Standardization
363.content:
Enforce standardized metadata requirements for all testing constitution rules to ensure consistency and machine-readability.


Requirements:
- Require complete metadata including rule_id, title, category, description, severity_level
- Mandate version, effective_date, last_updated, last_updated_by, applicability fields
- Enforce policy_linkage object with policy_version_ids[] and policy_snapshot_hash

364.title: Standardized Test Reporting Framework
364.content:
Establish mandatory standardized reporting formats for all test executions including both human-readable and machine-processable outputs.


Requirements:
- Require JUnit XML or equivalent test result format emission
- Mandate signed JSONL receipt lines summarizing constitutional adherence
- Enforce append-only JSONL policy with comprehensive receipt field inclusion

365.title: Add Module Procedure
365.content:
To add a module: create both canonical folders (STR-003/STR-004); add required snapshots and keys (SCH-001‚Ä¶SCH-006); then pass all CI checks (VAL-001‚Ä¶VAL-007).


Requirements:
- Create both extension and GSMD folders per canonical mapping (STR-003, STR-004)
- Add messages and receipts_schema snapshots with required keys (SCH-001)
- Pass all automated checks (VAL-001 through VAL-007)

366.title: Remove Module Procedure
366.content:
To remove a module: delete both canonical folders; update any enumerations/mappings; re-run CI to ensure no dangling references (VAL-001).


Requirements:
- Remove both extension and GSMD folders
- Update mapping enumerations
- Re-run CI to ensure no dangling references (VAL-001)

367.content:
Each GSMD module MUST contain:
‚Ä¢ `messages/v1/snapshot.json` with `messages.problems`, `messages.status_pill`, `messages.cards`
‚Ä¢ `receipts_schema/v1/snapshot.json` with `receipts.required`, `receipts.optional`

- Every module MUST provide `receipts_schema/v1/snapshot.json` with `receipts.required` and `receipts.optional` keys

368.content:
Every `.../v1/snapshot.json` MUST include all required top-level fields defined in the Constitution.


Requirements:
- Each snapshot JSON MUST include: `snapshot_id`, `module_id`, `slug`, `version`, `schema_version`, `policy_version_ids`, `snapshot_hash`, `signature`, `kid`, `effective_from`, `evaluation_points`, `messages`, `rollout`, `observability`, `privacy`, `evidence`, `receipts`, `tests`

`schema_version` MUST equal "1.0.0" and `version.major` MUST equal `1`.

- `version.major` MUST equal 1

Validate `messages.problems`, `messages.status_pill`, `messages.cards` exist in `messages/v1/snapshot.json`.


Requirements:
- Validate `messages.problems`, `messages.status_pill`, `messages.cards` exist in `messages/v1/snapshot.json`

380.title: CI: Validate Receipts Schema Keys
380.content:
Validate `receipts.required` and `receipts.optional` exist in `receipts_schema/v1/snapshot.json`.


Requirements:
- Validate `receipts.required` and `receipts.optional` exist in `receipts_schema/v1/snapshot.json`

381.title: CI: Validate Snapshot Version Pair
381.content:
Validate `schema_version == "1.0.0"` and `version.major == 1` in all snapshots.


Requirements:
- Validate `schema_version == "1.0.0"` in all snapshots
- Validate `version.major == 1` in all snapshots

382.title: CI: Validate KID Format
382.content:
Validate `kid` contains "ed25519" in all snapshots.


Requirements:
- Validate `kid` contains "ed25519" in all snapshots

383.title: CI: Validate Evaluation Points Type
383.content:
Validate `evaluation_points` is a list/array.


Requirements:
- Validate `evaluation_points` is a list/array in all snapshots

384.title: Prioritize Determinism Over Speed
384.content:
Reproducible test runs are superior to fast but flaky runs.


Requirements:
- Configure test frameworks to prioritize reproducible outcomes over execution speed.

385.title: Eliminate Test-Result Caching
385.content:
Disable or purge all framework caches before every run.


Requirements:
- Treat cached test discovery or compiled output as defect sources.

386.title: Enforce Hermetic Test Runs
386.content:
Tests must not access network, system clocks, global OS state, or previous runs.


Requirements:
- All tests operate in complete isolation without external dependencies.

387.title: Maintain Test Independence
387.content:
Tests must pass when run alone or in any sequence.


Requirements:
- Each test must be completely self-contained without shared state.

388.title: Maintain Standard Repository Structure
388.content:
Use src/, tests/ with subdirectories unit/, component/, integration/, fixtures/, helpers/.


Requirements:
- Adhere to standardized directory hierarchy with clear separation.

389.title: Use Standard Test Naming Conventions
389.content:
Python: test_*.py or *_test.py; TypeScript/JavaScript: *.test.(ts|js) or *.spec.(ts|js).


Requirements:
- Follow established naming patterns for automatic test discovery.

390.title: Purge Cache Directories Pre-Execution
390.content:
Delete Python, Node.js, and tooling caches before test execution.


Requirements:
- Remove all designated cache directories before test execution begins.

391.title: Disable Framework Caching
391.content:
Use framework-specific flags to disable caching mechanisms.


Requirements:
- Configure pytest, Jest, Vitest, Mocha with explicit cache-disabling flags.

392.title: Maintain Unit Test Purity
392.content:
Unit tests must be pure functions with no I/O, network, or time dependencies.


Requirements:
- Unit tests operate without external dependencies, network calls, or time-based behavior.

393.title: Use Table-Driven Test Structure
393.content:
Unit tests must use table-driven tests for clarity.


Requirements:
- Employ table-driven patterns with test cases in structured data format.

394.title: Use In-Memory Doubles for Component Tests
394.content:
Component tests must use in-memory doubles only for cross-module interactions.


Requirements:
- Employ in-memory test doubles (mocks, stubs, fakes) avoiding real external systems.

395.title: Use Real Adapters for Integration Tests
395.content:
Integration tests must use real adapters with isolated instances.


Requirements:
- Employ real adapters and drivers with in-process instances or containerized dependencies.

396.title: Prohibit Internet Access in Tests
396.content:
No calls to public Internet in unit, component, or integration tests.


Requirements:
- Tests must not make calls to public Internet services or external APIs.

397.title: Control Randomness and Time
397.content:
All randomness must be seeded; time must be frozen or explicitly controlled.


Requirements:
- Use TEST_RANDOM_SEED for randomness and time-freezing helpers for temporal behavior.

398.title: Prohibit Test Retries
398.content:
Flaky tests are bugs; do not mask with retries.


Requirements:
- Test frameworks must not employ automatic retry mechanisms.

399.title: Organize Fixtures and Data
399.content:
Fixtures under tests/fixtures/, read-only, prefer synthetic data, hash large fixtures.


Requirements:
- Locate fixtures in designated directory, use read-only access, prefer synthetic data, record hashes for large fixtures.

400.title: Generate Test Evidence
400.content:
Emit jUnit XML reports and run manifest with seeds, versions, and hashes.


Requirements:
- Produce standardized machine-readable output artifacts for each test execution.

401.title: Design AI-Generated Tests Deterministically
401.content:
Assume cache purging, use TEST_RANDOM_SEED, compose hermetic tests.


Requirements:
- AI-generated tests must be deterministic, hermetic, and cache-independent.

402.title: Organize AI-Generated Tests Properly
402.content:
Place tests in correct directories, use pure helpers, minimize dependencies.


Requirements:
- Follow directory structure, create pure helper functions, prefer standard libraries.

403.title: Ensure AI-Generated Test Quality
403.content:
Limit test scope, provide complete implementations, create actionable failures.


Requirements:
- Tests must be focused, complete, runnable, and have clear failure messages.

404.title: Enforce Quality Gates
404.content:
All tests must pass, no network access, valid artifacts, cache elimination verified.


Requirements:
- Test runs succeed only when meeting all quality criteria.

405.title: Conduct Comprehensive Test Reviews
405.content:
Verify determinism, completeness, organization, harness usage, artifacts, cache elimination.


Requirements:
- Code reviews must validate all test quality aspects before approval.

406.title: Enforce Static Package Contributions
406.content:
All package.json contributions (commands, menus, views, keybindings, configuration) must be statically defined at package build time. Runtime modification or dynamic addition of VS Code extension contributions is strictly prohibited.


Requirements:
- package.json contributions MUST exist at package time; Runtime mutation NOT allowed

407.title: Restrict Scope to IDE Surfaces Only
407.content:
The extension scope is strictly limited to IDE-only surfaces including Status Pill, Decision Card, Evidence Drawer, Quick Actions, and Receipt. Web UI development is explicitly excluded from scope.


Requirements:
- Defines scope as IDE-only surfaces (Status Pill ‚Üí Decision Card ‚Üí Evidence Drawer ‚Üí Quick Actions ‚Üí Receipt); explicitly excludes web UI

408.title: Exclude Server and Policy Definitions
408.content:
This constitution governs only the VS Code extension architecture and explicitly excludes definitions for server endpoints or policy content.


Requirements:
- Specifies this constitution does not define server endpoints or policy content

409.title: Ensure Fast Extension Activation
409.content:
The extension activation function must return quickly, with all heavy initialization work deferred to command handlers to prevent VS Code startup delays.


Requirements:
- activate() MUST return quickly; heavy work MUST be deferred to command handlers

410.title: Implement Context Key Driven Menus
410.content:
All menu visibility and enablement must be controlled through VS Code context keys using setContext commands and when clauses.


Requirements:
- Menus MUST be driven via setContext and when clauses

411.title: Standardize Single Status Bar Item
411.content:
The extension must use a single shared Status Bar item with composition logic rather than multiple individual status items.


Requirements:
- Standardize on single shared Status Bar item with composition logic

412.title: Enforce Single Extension Artifact
412.content:
The repository must produce and distribute exactly one VS Code extension artifact. Multi-extension packaging is strictly prohibited.


Requirements:
- Repository MUST ship one extension artifact; multi-extension packaging NOT permitted

413.title: Maintain Canonical Directory Structure
413.content:
The project must exactly follow the authoritative directory structure defined in the constitution without deviation.


Requirements:
- Must follow specified directory layout exactly as defined

414.title: Isolate Core Framework Code
414.content:
The src/core/ directory must contain only shared framework code. Product-specific logic is strictly prohibited in core.


Requirements:
- src/core/ contains shared framework code only; Product logic MUST NOT be placed in core/

415.title: Contain Features in Module Directories
415.content:
All feature implementation code must reside within src/modules/<slug>/ directories with the specified file structure.


Requirements:
- All feature code MUST live under src/modules/<slug>/ with specified files
